reviewText:
Tower(Defence) = Guns / Turrets + Bullets(Lots)*Missiles
Tower defence games often follow a formula, whereby you obey certain rules and fulfill certain criteria. Good tower defence games make this process happen invisibly and provide an experience that is both addictive and challenging, games like the seminal Defence Grid, which is considered the benchmark upon which all other Tower Defence games must be looked upon.

Comparing Terrorhedron to a Tower Defence game isn't really possible, because if Tower Defence is a formula, then Terrorhedron is algebra. It is mathematical purity and brilliance, expressed in abstract form. In most Tower Defence games you have a fixed path upon which the creeps will run and try to get to your base, you may be able to mess with this path by placing towers down, or you may have fixed locations upon which to build your towers.

Wait, what, I have root? ... I have root... muwahahahhaha. I HAVE ROOT!
In this case you do have fixed starting locations from which to build upon, but where it departs from the norm in this case is that the tower build points are merely bases, and from there you add lego like snap connectors from which towers can grow, tree like from the root node. The game takes full advantage of this, with levels working on every single plane of a three dimensional maze, often weaving complicated, tangled paths over cubes or more complex surfaces, allowing you to maximise your opportunities if you're clever and are willing to be imaginative.

That's the key bit, because you can use the snap connectors freely, the only limitation is really funds and how crazy you can get with the tower layout, want to build mighty archways with laser turrets hanging off? Go nuts. I just did for a section of the first level, and it worked beautifully. Here, you -build- the towers, step by step.

Depth of field? Check. Abstract polygons? Check. Chiptunes? Check.
With such an expansive canvas, the aesthetic comes as a relief, being clean and abstract, minimalist but without looking amateur, game looks slick, well rendered, and has a thumping soundtrack, and doesn't suffer any framerate issues, regardless of what mayhem is going on at the time, and the clean design of the level layout allows you to keep focussed on the action. Doing the tutorial is mandatory this time, because Terrorhedron requires you to adapt to the fact that this game will have you building corners, arches, bridges, and all kinds of things to create your own defensive setups.

Enemies in this game are represented in a similarly abstract manner, simple three dimensional shapes with various colours representing their health, it keeps things simple and allows for absolutely ridiculous levels of enemies on the screen at once, when combined with the insane combinations of bases and towers, this can turn into an exceptionally busy game in a real hurry. It keeps scaling as you go, so when your carefully constructed strategy begins to falter, you may find that you have to re-engineer and expand to ever greater feats of lunacy to keep the enemies at bay.

Terrorhedron University is open, enroll today.
In Terrorhedron you take pretty much every principle you've learned from other Tower Defence games and then extend and amplify those concepts, turning them from basics to pure, abstracted concepts. In effect, the game takes the genre, strips away all the things that aren't needed and then refines what there is and adds a few key elements that in turn fundamentally require the player to abandon the comfort zone of just build a tower"

reviewText:
I've been playing TD games since the original StarCraft, and Terrorhedron is refreshingly unique amongst the genre.  This is a fun and interesting take on Tower Defense which can be very challenging.

There are a variety of towers which you might expect in TD, such as single-target lasers, splashing cannons, and slow towers to name a few.  Where it gets complicated is the limited numbers and orientations of mounting points along the map.  This is when you turn to your 4-sided tetrahedrons and 6-sided cube pieces in order to expand your defensible area, which also allows you to place towers in otherwise-blind spots for coverage.

Upon the last enemy's death (or when it reaches the gate and you lose lives) the round pauses for building phase.  Use this time to experiment with angles to maximize coverage of your turrets.  Any pieces you place during this time can be sold for their full cost, but once the building phase ends, all of these pieces will only be worth ~50% from then on.

If you like TD and want a fresh, fun, and challenging new game to play, buy Terrorhedron.

reviewText:
Terrerohedron is a tower defence game with a lot of promise and is very addictive!

The concept is of a standard tower defence game but the map is in three dimensions, at first this can confuse and be disorienting but after a few games you will be spinning the map round and planning your kill zones with relative ease.

I normally like TD games that allow you to maze and shape the route that the enemy takes TH does not let you do this but gets very tactical as you can build in three dimensions, you place extendable blocks and then place towers on them or more extendable blocks. This makes looking at the map in all dimensions and then thinking of how you will build a 3d kill zone in an area quite rewarding.

There is not a huge amount of variety in the towers but the game does give 3-4 solid different play sets with towers you can choose from, it feels good when you enclose a complete section and then have towers that the bullets bounce back and forth to deal a crazy amount of damage.

There are also some great additions that should be in all TD games, a damage counter for each tower for each round and a total so that you can see tactics that work better or towers lagging behind. A huge choice in different target priorities for every single tower, this is something that should be standard in all TD games!

The game has multiplayer also and at a recent lAN 3 of us spent far longer than we would have thought trying to improve our game and win together. It is a nice addition to the game and adds a lot more hours of fun to it.

The game is definitely a small indie game that is what I hope the first edition, I got it on 95% sale and paid 19 pence for the game and so my following niggles not so much pan the game but are improvements I would love to see on the TH2 and I will pay more than 19 Pence for it!

The units that you try to destroy are multisided shapes and you take off sides until they have no sides left and they are destroyed. This makes it quite hard later on to identify how bad the threat is as one moving unit could end up costing you the game as it has more than 100 sides and thus all your lives. I would assume this was done for ease but even some that glow would be helpful.

The camera can get very disorientating and annoying to use, there are hotkeys to mark camera points and I recommend you use them. When you build an enclosed box it is hard to select towers to build.

In multiplayer even the fastest game setting is quite slow and makes it quite slow to play.

There are quite a few challenging difficulties and an impossible mode, this is not for the feint hearted and one map took me nearly 3 hours before I eventually lost, unfortunately most of the time in this was trying to spend the huge amount of money I got each round and it would take 10-15 minutes to spend it all. This is a small gripe as this mode is not to played that often but a quicker way to build would be nice. Also anyone who likes Minecraft would love this mode as it turns into a TD version of it.

All in all, this game is very interesting if feeling like it has a lot more to be unlocked at some point. I highly recommend getting it even if you just play some of the easier settings on a few maps, it makes you think and mixes up the tower defence area.

Oh and I loved the soundtrack, one of the few games I play with music on. Make Terrerhedron 2!!!

reviewText:
While this is strictly a tower defence game, the convention will only go so far as having enemies that moved in a pre-determined path and the fact that you construct towers to defeat said enemies. To succeed in this game, you must have to the mental fortitude to plan in three dimensions, as well as an abundance of creativity to maximise and extend the reach of your turrets based on limited nodes to build upon.

In the first hour of play you’ll learn to construct vine like constructs to maximise your firepower, since you can only place turrets on specified nodes or extend upon them via connectors. Balancing between the reach of your foundations and your capacity to damage, you’ll glow new vines across a few strategic points, eventually connecting them all in one gigantic network. All between rounds of steadily increasing waves.

The game can be mercilessly hard at higher difficulties, but it is also a rewarding experience to players that can adapt new tactics in different elevations and angles.

That said, the multiplayer felt tagged on at the last minute and it suffers from sync issues when I tried it. The lack of a map editor is also a major oversight on the developer’s part, as this could have so much potential if it had workshop support; potential that was wasted simply because the devs wished to work on a newer title.

If you wanted a relatively new take on the tower defence genre, you ought to give this a try. The unique visuals and catchy tunes are just icing if you happened to like the retro theme.

This is a must have for every tower Defense Fan!  It took me a while to get used to the 3d profile and building the tower bases but the learning curve is part of the fun and challenge to most Tower D games. That is the case here as well.  A mouse is a must in my opinion.  If you are used to a track pad you could probably manage though. The gameplay is pretty much the same as most tower d in principle.  Different 3-d shapes move around a set 3-d track.  You set towers in set places on the track and blow 'shells' - think layers- off of different shapes until there is nothing left and the shape is obliterated.  You also have a couple choices of bases that allow you to build more than one tower in a spot.  Use slows and offensive towers to kill all the shapes without running out of lives and you will beat the track.      It also has trading cards and achieves for those that are interested.  I had bought it at the super cheap price of .24 cents but it is one of the few games that I would say is worth the full price.

As a fun tower defense game, I can say there is nothing onscreen that isn't needed. After 5 minutes I turned off all Audio ingame as it is just a small set of annoying sounds, a stock robot voice and infuriatingly annoying music. The menu music is too loud for it's own right. But, I do enjoy this game. Tower Defense games are immensely fun, and this is no exception. I would get it while it is on sale, otherwise, I would hold your money and get another TD game. This feels like it should be in early access though, so be warned. It is rough around the edges, I am unable to get Multiplayer Co-Op working, and did I mention the horrible audio effects? Yes? Well, I will until they're changed.

The gun variety. This is something I would file as neutral instead of just good or bad. It has good variety, from the stock Laser turret (essentially a short burst machine gun turret) to the EMP turret which slows down enemies (but is not worth the money, keep away as it is faulted massively). I like the plama turrets. They are very nifty for when there is a distance to cover with a lot of power needed. I tend to put them near to the entry point.

The EMP turret is very bad. I thought it would be helpful but took me 10 rounds to realise the geo is only slowed down until it gets shot. Why would they chose this as a design decision? It is very strange in my opinion. But the other turrets do suffice in how well they work, just stay off of the EMP.

All in all, this game is fun and a good distraction, not the best TD game. Not the most well made game in general either. It's UI is about as bland as the UI from Bad Rats. And we all know how terrible that game was, dont we...

If you have some money to spare from maybe some steam trading cards, go for it, it's worth a buy then. But for the $5 marking price I personally wouldn't go for it. There are plenty of other TD games out there for such a low price with much higher content and a lot more well made than this one. But for a game which you can lose hours in , I don't regret ny purchase one bit.

reviewText:
This is a really fun, but has some problems.

Pros:

Change turrent behavior: In most Tower Defense games, the most powerful towers are also the slowest. If they shoot the weaklings, then the strong enemies have a chance to slip past it. This game lets you make these towers target only the strongest enemies. This is the biggest pro in my opinion.

Build bigger platforms: There are special 4 way and 6 way blocks. These allow you to build more towers in one space. These blocks can be put together, like legos
date:
to create chains of towers. Also, towers can't shoot things below them, so sometimes you need a these blocks to tilt the towers.

Simple: No fancy PC slowing effects or confusing menus.

Hard: I couldn't complete the first level on easy until I unlocked the best turrent.

Cons:

Extreamly slow camera zoom: I litteraly seen turtles craw faster than this camera zooms. Furthermore, I have looked through the entire program files, and there appears to be no way to change it. (If someone found a way, then please let me know.)

Flawed EMP behavior: The EMPs will NEVER shoot an enemy that has already been shot by one, even after the effet wears off.  This means only the first couple turrents will work.

Can't rotate 4 sided platform: These have angled sides, and sometimes they don't work well simply because the angle is wrong. Rotating these would make them much more useful.

Mismatched Acheivements: There are achievements for unlocking things and completing levels, but you never get the right one. Example: completing the Fortress level on easy unlocks the acheivements for completing the Gateway level on easy.

Multiplayer is LAN only.

Fun and interesting variation of tower defense

Multiplayer

Only 6 maps

Overall:
I would recommend this game to anyone who has a love for tower defense games, or is looking for a unique strategy game. Certainly unique and fun to play. I personally got this game as a gift from a friend when it was on sale for around a quarter, but the game might be worth the $5 for some people. reviewText:
A cheap standard Tower Defence game which gives value for money.

There's not a huge amount of content in Terrorhedron but enough to give you a decent amount of game time.

It has 6 maps which are in 3D letting the tracks twist and bend around.
There's a limited amount of build locations on the maps however you can expand from them with extension blocks to have as many towers as you can buy.. or as many as your computer can handle.
You have several turrets which you can place on them however I found myself using the same tactic throughout all the levels which left some of them redundant, i felt like more could have been done to make the others more useful and give you more ways of passing the waves of attack.

One of the odd things that I didn’t like when I first started playing was how the towers unlocked, what you start with weren’t good enough and meant failing, once unlocked they stayed unlocked so it was a little pointless to go through.

There’s several difficulty settings which give more waves of attacks, plenty of hours can be put into completing the game but I really do wish there were more to it.

Unlike nearly all Tower Defence games, Multiplayer Co-op is available and for up to 8 people.

Anyone into Tower Defence should enjoy it and Terrorhedron goes on sale quite frequently for a high discount so it’s definitely worth a shot if you pick it up on sale however it really isn’t much at full price for the time you get out it.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: The game is buggy, the interface is unintuitive and the multiplayer is sometimes completely out-of-synch.

Still! Recommended, because you can get it dirt cheap and get good laughs.

Good:
- Fun concept.
- Simple and neat 3D design.
- You can save viewpoints for good navigation inbetween.
- Balanced leveling up.

Bad:
- I find the turrent/element placement unintuitive. You have to click on the place you want it, then click on what you put on there, as opposed to selecting the element you want to put down and then the place. Sometimes it gets confusing which place you have selected, so you can put the element in the wrong place.
- Can't see what range the turret would have in the desired place before putting it down.
- Bugs. EMP seems to shoot incosistently, multiplayer (played on LAN) was out-of-synch lot of times.
- Can't control the angle of the extending elements.

The hilarious:
- When you save up all your money on a big fancy turret but you don't put it where you wanted to because you accidentally had another place selected.

For what we got this game for, it was very funny, but it definitely needs polishing.

However, the isn't implemented into the UI well.  Locked tower types are greyed out before you've unlocked them.  The problem is that all unlocked towers stay highlighted, even when you don't have enough money to buy them.  I frequently try to buy towers when I don't have enough money, assume that I bought them, and look back to see they're not there.  There's no you can't buy this" error noise

no flashing X over the button... just nothing.

reviewText:
As a fan of the Tower Defense Genre I believe this game to be far too complicated in terms of defense layout creation.

You may begin construction of your defenses upon developer chosen insert points and nowhere else. On these points you may construct either a defense tower or install a triple adaptor and/or extension in order to set up defenses for parts of the level which do not have these insert points. These adaptors can be stacked as much as you like...

I have no quarrel with unlimited creativity but when it stems up, down, left and right with unlimited avenues it begins to lose its charm quite quickly as you have so much option but very little drive to do so. There is no game atmosphere to give you any reason to play...

Infinite ways of stemming out from insert points creates a game based on extreme patience and testing; something I nor most of my friends have.

Also, the theme of this game is very dull with simplistic cube styled levels, mostly unimaginative towers and enemies that are just difference shapes and colours to represent how much damage they can take as they travel through the maze... No, you cannot plan out the maze, only the defenses.

This game just gets boring extremely quickly and doesn't allow you to do a simple restart even if you DO manage to maintain focus upon this game.

If the theme was changed and each tower felt like it provided a more unique and useful design then this concept could become an okay game. The problem really is that this game is just an unimaginative geometrical bore which will most likely find you quitting not because you failed, but because you failed to get to the point of failure.

This is boring and dull but could be made better with the existence of some imaginative graphics and more interesting concepts.

This game I would rate a 35/100 due to its boring gameplay, unimaginative style, Lack of polish and the biggest no no of tower defense games: Leaving out a RESTART LEVEL button.

There are better games out there which will provide more fun and charm, including veteran TD players.

TLDR:
8/10 Great tower defense game

Full Review:
Terrorhedron takes the traditional tower defense formula and adds a twist by having the game utilize three dimensions rather than the traditional two. This is an interesting change to the tower defense formula and adds a new layer of strategy. The other main difference Terrorhedron adds is the ability to build connector blocks to tower locations, meaning you can turn a single tower slot into a defensive megastructure.

The music is great and really adds to the minimalist tech feel that the game provides. The enemies are all colored shapes which change depending on how many hits they can take. Towers are unlocked throughout play at a reasonable pace, I never really felt like I was grinding for a new tower or being given too many options too quickly. You can also upgrade your towers which generally provides them with a new ability rather than just a stat boost, which is great.

I can't think of any real problems with this game. I have been having a ton of fun with Terrorhedron and if you are a fan of tower defense games I think you would too.

reviewText:
Terrorhedron is a nice and simple tower defense game with a unique mechanic that really changes the way you play these types of games. This game is great if your like me and your internet isn't the fastest in the world and you have to wait for youtube video's to load. Creating a fun and unique experience with a suprisingly challenging gameplay when you get to the higher difficulties and levels.

Terrorhedron dosen't offer anything special with graphics, with the area just being white and black blocks with very minimal decal. And the background being space themed, but in all honesty is suffices for what this game is trying to achieve, this game is really not about the graphics and more on gameplay.

Now what makes Terrorhedron much more different and unique from the rest of the tower defense games is that they have included a 4-way platform and a 6-way platfrom. These add a way more immense gameplay than any other tower defense game. These platfroms can be placed and create almost an infinite amount of possibilites you could do to place your various turrets, allowing for amazing strageties. This makes it so you are not just stricted to a set amount of places you can place your turrets in and even create a wall of just turrets destroying all the shapes in your way! The turret selection is nice and standart, you got your normal laser turret and your aoe turret but nothing amazing or special like you see from games such as the balloons tower defense.

Also a very nice addition to the game is the ability to play multiplayer, which is a nice feature to have. Though after playing a couple of matches with friends, you find out that the money system being split into two is a little broken as if you sell one of your turrets, the money will instead go to your friends which can be annoying and also I feel like sometimes me and my friend don't earn enough money after a round which leaves us with 90-100 which is only half of what I have to pay for a single basic turret. Another thing is that it's not synchronized with the other person, for example, one person might have already finished a round but your still stuck on the last cube being destroyed. It can sometimes mess up the game and the stragety you are going for, atleast in my experience.

Full Review:
Terrorhedron takes the traditional tower defense formula and adds a twist by having the game utilize three dimensions rather than the traditional two. This is an interesting change to the tower defense formula and adds a new layer of strategy. The other main difference Terrorhedron adds is the ability to build connector blocks to tower locations, meaning you can turn a single tower slot into a defensive megastructure.

The music is great and really adds to the minimalist tech feel that the game provides. The enemies are all colored shapes which change depending on how many hits they can take. Towers are unlocked throughout play at a reasonable pace, I never really felt like I was grinding for a new tower or being given too many options too quickly. You can also upgrade your towers which generally provides them with a new ability rather than just a stat boost, which is great.

I can't think of any real problems with this game. I have been having a ton of fun with Terrorhedron and if you are a fan of tower defense games I think you would too.

reviewText:
WOW.  This game's awesome.  Concept's the same as all other TD games, the little creeps that you have to kill travel on a set path, and you have several fixed tower positions.  But the awesome thing is that you're able to build base blocks with MORE tower spots on them.  So let's say on a map, you've got just one tower spot to build on.  You could put a cube-shaped base block on that spot, giving you five more build spots on that block (top and the 4 sides).  On top of that cube, you could put ANOTHER cube-shaped base block, so now you've got 8 sides and 1 top build spot.  So far, I've seen the cube-shaped base block and a triangle-shaped base block, not sure if there are more to come, but with just these two, the possibilities are endless.

The turrets, I have yet to get the hang of.  Sometimes I'll place a turret in a spot and think it's gonna fire and be very effective, but it just won't function at all.  But, if you build to check out the turret's firing distance/directions, and then sell BEFORE you start the round, the tower/baseblock sells for full price.  You're always getting XP and unlocking stuff, too, so losing doesn't even feel terrible.  Feels almost like I'm MORE encouraged to play as I lose, making mistakes is rewarding me with more skill.  I dunno, I love it so far.

There's maybe a half hour learning curve.  The camera's tough to get the hang of at first, the UI's really barebones, and I'm not able to find a controls section (probably isn't one), but if it's possible to rotate the base blocks, I definitely want to know how.  Also turned the music off -immediately- because no sir.  Developers, if you're reading this, I can compose a far better soundtrack for you, or just let you use an instrumental album I've already written/recorded.

I just can't stress enough how great the gameplay is.  Anything in this review that even sounds remotely like a drawback, it's a minor gripe that I honestly don't care about.  Bells and whistles can go to hell.  The strategy in this game is second to none.

8.5/10.  Maybe a 9.  I'd give it a 10 if it came with flashier graphics (I'm picturing RUSH meets Defense Grid 2), the ability to rotate base blocks, an easier camera, and a pause button.  Took me 20 minutes to know I'll be playing this game for years to come.  Basic UI, basic graphics, and GENIUS, spectacular, limitless gameplay.
